title: Mage Viability
body: It's really sad to see that only a few mages are ever truly viable at any given time now-a-days. I'm tired of seeing the safe, easy to use, high damage, low risk mages in every game. Why bother picking high risk skillshot champs like {{champion:99}}  or {{champion:101}}  when the reward is the same with safer picks like the boring old {{champion:61}} ,{{champion:134}}, {{champion:69}},{{champion:163}}  ? The problem with mages is that even though they're SUPPOSED to be the magical bursty class, only the ones with short cd aoe/targetted and therefore high dps mages are picked. Gone are the days where hard to land skillshot combos are rewarded with mages. The risk is simply too high. With AP items constantly getting the shaft in terms of cost efficiency compared to AD items, it seems the pool of viable mages keeps shrinking smaller and smaller. Let's not even mention how these same champions require half the mana, time, and sometimes even half the cds ({{champion:112}} ) needed to clear waves. Don't get me wrong, I know buffing long range mages would just let them 100-0 you from fog of war, but I'd really like to see these risky picks have higher payoffs than they do now. Burst means almost nothing this season with the clusterfuck of shields and heals flying around, but at least AD assassins hardly ever have to land single target skillshots to do their job, and even so, their auto attacks still hurt like trucks while long range mages have to sit around sucking their thumbs until their cds are up again once they miss. Overall, I feel like this season has the been the worst season in terms of champion viability and I'm not expecting Rito to have any bright ideas... ever really. Until then, let's just all play the good ol AD Ranged Point Click Sustained Burst DPS sub-class consisting of {{champion:119}} {{champion:29}} {{champion:67}} {{champion:18}}

I think wording is causing us to disagree.

Lux has a 47.8% winrate according to the very website you listed.

Also, look at pickrates, there are a few mages with incredibly high winrates, but they have 1% playrates.  So it's almost entirely just mains and one-tricks playing them.  The only mages that have both high pickrate and high winrate are Malzahar, TF, Vlad, and Anivia.  Every other mage is either mediocre, propped up by mains, or is struggling.

Compare this to assassins, who have much higher pickrates and still better winrates.  Talon has the highest winrate mid other than Aurelion, who is only played by mains, and Malzahar, who is unbelievably broken.  Only LeBlanc has a winrate under 49%, and next up is Akali, who is played Top almost exclusively and has a great winrate there.  Every single other midlane assassin has a winrate above 50%.
Except Lux is bad design and won't be viable with her current kit so your point isn't relevant.

She could become a good deal healthier if they shifted more of her damage into her passive, encouraging her to proc it as many times as possible rather than just the single time in her typical burst combo that people hate.  I think they'd have to buff her shield or her cds a little though so she can actually try to autoattack without always getting blown up herself.

Note: these are not serious ideas for balancing her or even what I think should be done.  Just a random thought on what could give her kit both greater reliability (her main weakness) and greater interaction (she actually goes up to her enemies).
Never said she wasn't.

me to to be honest, like void staff is a great item, but you only really get the full eficency of void staff when the enemy team is stacking high ammounts of magic resist. for 30 percent of spirit visage (assuming it's their one and only mr item) just isn't that much, now if they stacked spirit visage and a 2nd major MR item, than yeah, Void staff is doing some hard core work.

We could really use a new AP item that just has normal flat magic penetration.

Void Staff adds more damage than Deathcap in most if not all scenarios because simply negating another ~15 MR or so against a champion with just MR blues adds more damage (since it usually helps bring their MR close to 0) or CLOSE TO the same amount of damage as Deathcap.....while being about 1000g cheaper. 

2 things need to happen if they want to broaden out penetration. 1 is they obviously need to add more pen options (while arguably making Haunting Guise not the only base and making the stat more accessible outside of a horrible build path 1500g item). The second is they would need to make Void Staff be based off Bonus Magic Resist much like the Last Whisper line. Before MR items Void Staff can already shred about 20 MR or so from a tank through base MR alone and then another 30% on top of that makes MR very.....mediocre in some scenarios if it is a actual tank busting mage (Malz/Brand/Cassio) and why Adaptive Helm gets its "absurd" passive because that is really the only way tanks can build MR against these characters since you can't do much when Malzahar shreds 60 MR off you from his boots+VS+Liandry's and then also do massive %max health damage with R.

A lot of a mid lane mage's safety comes not in their disengage ability, but with their waveclear proficiency. Lux has to use her only consistent damage tool (E) to farm, WHICH CANT EVEN 1SHOT backline casters, thus causing her to walk up into dangerous territory to get cs. Meanwhile, Taliyah can walk up one time, use e followed by a q or two depending on the stage of the game, and wipe out the whole wave, while lux's e is STILL on CD. This leaves lux to either let the minions fall into her tower and lose cs, and/or tank the minions with her shield to get them, costing her even MORE mana and dueling capability.
